title: Fr Seraphim Holland Q&A | Answering Your Orthodox Questions | AMA
description:
*subscribe for more*
Joining me today is Fr Seraphim Holland to answer your Orthodox Questions. 

About Fr Seraphim in his own words.
Excerpt from his testimony:

There is so much *beauty* in Orthodoxy that I do not see in Protestantism, and Orthodox are also quite far away from the neo-platonist tendencies of some Protestants. Some emphasize reason so much that they seem to forget that man has a body and a soul, and that God, who is totally free and beautiful, having made man in His image, has given man an inherent love for beauty. The Orthodox, worship God *naturally*, and not just with cold blooded reason, but also with their God given feelings and intuition.

In Orthodoxy, a man is not "saved" in an event. He is transformed, and is like a sapling that grows towards the light, and he loves God more and more, because "He first loved us" [14]. Because of his love for God, and his ascetical struggles (to win the kingdom of Heaven by violence), God helps to change him, and his will slowly, imperceptibly conforms to the perfect will of God. He becomes like God; he shares in the energy of God. We call this process "theosis", and this is salvation. It is not just intellectual assent, and it is not just ascetical endeavor, which some call "works". It is a synergy of the two. The first follows the other, and the other empowers a man to do the first.

#orthodox #protestant #apologetics

title: New Scholarship That PROVES First Century Icon Veneration?
description:
*Subscribe* 

Joining me today is Evangelos from Scriptorium Press to discuss a HUGE breakthrough in scholarship that may reveal evidence of first century icon veneration, prayers for the dead AND the episcopacy. New evidence has come to light surrounding the corpus of "Pseudo" Dionysius that claims the corpus is actually genuine to the first century. 

Let's explore this new evidence and dive into this very important subject for the advancement of apologetics dialogue on icon veneration. 

#orthodox #protestant #apologetics 

Saint Dionysius the Areopagite, the disciple of Saint Paul, was a famous first-century bishop, theologian, and martyr from Athens. He is the author of some of the earliest theological treatises in the Church and an inexhaustible source of apostolic wisdom. Presented here for the first time in English is his authoritative biography written by the learned 9th-century monk Michael Syncellus, together with the story of his martyrdom in Gaul translated from an ancient Latin account. The picture that emerges is one of an inspired prophet, merciful pastor, and zealous missionary.

Get the book! 
https://www.scriptoriumpress.ca/#saint-dionysius

title: Fr Peter Heers AMA | Answering Your Orthodox Questions | Q&A
description:
*subscribe for more* 

Joining me today is Fr Peter Heers, known for his popular channel the Orthodox Ethos. This will be an AMA stream where Fr Heers will answer your Orthodox questions. Are you an inquirer? A Protestant with objections? A Roman Catholic? Ask your Orthodox related questions here. Don‚Äôt miss this stream! 

#orthodox #protestant #apologetics 

Subscribe to Orthodox Ethos! 

https://youtube.com/@orthodoxethos?si=24Ui5d_fZ_FMMmLV

Fr. Peter Heers was born in Texas and grew up near San Francisco. The son of an Anglican priest, in 1992 he and his entire family and parish converted to the Orthodox Church. In 1998 he came to Thessaloniki, Greece, in order to visit Mt. Athos. He lived in Thessaloniki from 1998 until 2017, when he was named Professor of Old and New Testament at Holy Trinity Orthodox Seminary, Jordanville, NY. He is married, with five children. 

Fr. Peter is the founder and first to serve as editor of Divine Ascent, A Journal of Orthodox Faith, and the founder and current head of Uncut Mountain Press. He is the author of "The Missionary Origins of Modern Ecumenism: Milestones Leading up to 1920," as well as the newly released title, in Greek: "The Ecclesiological Renovation of the Second Vatican Council: An Orthodox Examination of Baptism and the Church According to the Decree on Ecumenism." This was his doctoral thesis and was published in English in the Fall of 2015. 

Fr. Peter is also the translator of several books, including the "Life of Elder Paisios" and the "Epistles of Elder Paisios," "The Truth of our Faith" (vols 1&2) by Elder Cleopa and "Apostle to Zaire: The Life of Fr. Cosmas of Grigoriou," as well as the best-selling children's book "From I-ville to You-ville." 

Fr. Peter has a doctorate in Dogmatic Theology from the Theological School of the University of Thessalonica, where he has also completed is undergraduate studies and Masters degree in Dogmatic Theology. He served as the rector and spiritual father of the parish of the Holy Prophet Elias in Petrokerasa, a small village in the mountains outside of Thessalonica, Greece, from 2006 until 2017. In 2014 he was made Protopresbyteros and Spiritual Father of the Diocese of Ierissou and Agion Oros.

description:
The question of whether Jesus of Nazareth existed as a historical figure has been the subject of considerable debate, but there is a strong consensus among historians and scholars that Jesus did indeed exist. This consensus is based on historical evidence, both from Christian and non-Christian sources, as well as the criteria used in historical analysis. Here‚Äôs an overview of the main points:

Scholarly Consensus on Jesus‚Äô Existence

 1. Historical Agreement: The majority of historians, both secular and religious, agree that Jesus was a real person who lived in first-century Palestine. This view is supported by various ancient sources, despite differing opinions on the theological interpretations of his life. Historians typically distinguish between the ‚Äúhistorical Jesus‚Äù (the man who lived and was crucified) and the ‚ÄúChrist of faith‚Äù (the figure worshiped in Christianity).
 2. Non-Christian Sources: Several non-Christian sources from the ancient world mention Jesus or his followers. Some of the most significant include:
 ‚Ä¢ Tacitus: The Roman historian Tacitus, writing around 116 CE, refers to ‚ÄúChristus‚Äù who was executed by Pontius Pilate during the reign of Emperor Tiberius.
 ‚Ä¢ Josephus: The Jewish historian Josephus mentions Jesus in his Antiquities of the Jews (c. 93-94 CE). While one passage is disputed (the Testimonium Flavianum), a more minor reference to James, the brother of Jesus, is widely accepted as authentic.
 ‚Ä¢ Pliny the Younger and Suetonius also mention early Christians, who followed a man called ‚ÄúChrist.‚Äù
 3. Early Christian Sources: The New Testament, while theological in nature, is also considered a valuable historical source, particularly the Gospels and the letters of Paul. Most scholars agree that these texts contain a core of historical facts about Jesus, including his crucifixion, though the supernatural claims are not accepted as historical by non-religious historians.

title: Persecution in the name of atheism. #atheism #agnostic #atheist #christianity #christ #jesus #faith
description:
Atheist persecution of religion refers to instances in history where atheist or anti-religious ideologies have sought to suppress or eliminate religious beliefs and practices. These persecutions often arise in political contexts where atheism or secularism is linked to state policy, particularly under regimes that view religion as a threat to their power or as an impediment to social progress.

1. Soviet Union (1917-1991)

One of the most well-known examples of atheist persecution of religion occurred in the Soviet Union. Following the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917, the communist government led by Vladimir Lenin and later Joseph Stalin promoted state atheism as part of its Marxist ideology. The Russian Orthodox Church, along with other religious institutions, was viewed as a pillar of the old tsarist regime and a potential rival to the communist government. As a result, the state launched aggressive campaigns to reduce the influence of religion, including:

 ‚Ä¢ Confiscating church property
 ‚Ä¢ Closing religious institutions
 ‚Ä¢ Arresting, imprisoning, or executing clergy
 ‚Ä¢ Promoting atheist propaganda through education and media

Religious belief was portrayed as backward and superstitious, and many churches, mosques, and synagogues were destroyed or repurposed for secular uses.

2. Communist China (1949-present)

Under the leadership of Mao Zedong, the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) also adopted atheism as state policy after the founding of the People‚Äôs Republic of China in 1949. The government sought to weaken the influence of all religions, including Buddhism, Christianity, Islam, and traditional Chinese folk beliefs, through state control and repression. During the Cultural Revolution (1966-1976), religious persecution intensified, with religious sites destroyed, clergy persecuted, and religious practices banned.

Although religious freedom is nominally protected in modern China, the CCP continues to heavily regulate religious groups and crack down on ‚Äúunauthorized‚Äù religious activities. Persecution remains particularly severe for groups like the Falun Gong, Tibetan Buddhists, Uighur Muslims, and underground Christian churches.

3. Cambodia (1975-1979)

The Khmer Rouge regime, led by Pol Pot, was one of the most brutal atheist regimes in history. When the Khmer Rouge came to power in Cambodia in 1975, it implemented policies aimed at eradicating all forms of religion, along with other aspects of Cambodian culture. The Khmer Rouge viewed religion as counterrevolutionary, and its leaders sought to create a completely atheistic society.

During their rule, the Khmer Rouge executed monks, destroyed Buddhist temples, and forcibly converted the population to atheism. An estimated 90% of Cambodia‚Äôs Buddhist monks were either killed or disrobed, and many Christian missionaries and religious practitioners also suffered persecution.

description:
Miguel Pro, a Jesuit priest, was executed by a firing squad in Mexico on November 23, 1927, during the anti-Catholic persecutions of the Mexican Cristero War. Born in 1891, Pro was known for his joyful personality and dedication to his religious mission, especially as a priest during a time when the Catholic Church faced severe restrictions under the presidency of Plutarco El√≠as Calles.

The Calles Law, implemented in 1926, aimed to reduce the influence of the Catholic Church by restricting religious practices and rights. In response, many clergy members, including Pro, operated in secret to provide religious services. Pro returned to Mexico from Europe after his Jesuit training and worked covertly, disguising himself to administer the sacraments and support the faithful.

In 1927, Miguel Pro was falsely accused of involvement in an assassination attempt on √Ålvaro Obreg√≥n, a prominent political figure. Although there was no evidence linking Pro to the crime, the government used him as a scapegoat to suppress the growing Catholic resistance. His execution was intended as a public display to deter others from defying the regime.

On the day of his execution, Pro declined a blindfold, faced his executioners, and extended his arms in the shape of a cross, shouting ‚Äú¬°Viva Cristo Rey!‚Äù (‚ÄúLong live Christ the King!‚Äù) just before the shots were fired. This phrase became a rallying cry for the Cristeros, Catholic rebels who fought against the anti-religious policies of the government.

title: Atheist claims Jesus didn‚Äôt exist pt 3 #jesus #atheist #atheism #agnostic #christian #apologetics
description:
Hostile or non-Christian sources provide indirect but significant evidence for the historical existence of Jesus. These sources are often critical or dismissive of early Christianity but still reference Jesus or his followers, showing that Jesus was known to non-Christians in the ancient world. Here are some key examples of hostile citations:

1. Tacitus (c. 56-120 CE)

The Roman historian Tacitus mentions Jesus in his Annals (Book 15, Chapter 44), written around 116 CE. In his account of Nero‚Äôs persecution of Christians, he refers to ‚ÄúChristus,‚Äù who suffered the ‚Äúextreme penalty‚Äù (crucifixion) under Pontius Pilate during the reign of Tiberius. Tacitus clearly dislikes Christians, calling their faith a ‚Äúmischievous superstition,‚Äù but his writing confirms that Jesus was a historical figure who was executed.

2. Pliny the Younger (c. 61-113 CE)

Pliny, a Roman governor, wrote to Emperor Trajan around 112 CE, seeking advice on how to deal with Christians. In his letter, he describes Christians as worshipping ‚ÄúChristus‚Äù as a god. Pliny‚Äôs letter is not friendly toward Christianity but shows that Christians were numerous and devout, and that they worshipped a historical figure, Jesus.

3. Lucian of Samosata (c. 125-180 CE)

Lucian, a Greek satirist, mocks Christians and their beliefs in The Death of Peregrinus. He refers to Jesus as ‚Äúthe crucified one‚Äù and ridicules Christians for their devotion to him. Although hostile, Lucian‚Äôs writing suggests that Christians were widely known and that Jesus had a historical existence.

Eight days later, Jesus appeared again, this time with Thomas present. Jesus invited Thomas to touch his wounds, saying, ‚ÄúStop doubting and believe.‚Äù Confronted with the reality of the risen Jesus, Thomas responded with a profound declaration, ‚ÄúMy Lord and my God!‚Äù This statement is significant because it‚Äôs one of the clearest instances in the Gospels where someone directly acknowledges Jesus not only as Lord but as God.

title: Atheist persecution of religion #atheist #atheism #agnostic #christian #history #apologetics #jesus
description:
Mao Zedong‚Äôs atheist agenda was deeply intertwined with his broader political ideology and the goals of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP). As a Marxist, Mao embraced atheism as a key component of communism, which viewed religion as an instrument of oppression, historically used to justify inequality and the exploitation of the working class. For Mao, religion was not just a relic of the past, but also a challenge to the absolute authority of the state and its socialist agenda.

In his efforts to establish a secular, atheist state, Mao‚Äôs policies aggressively targeted religious institutions and practices. During the Cultural Revolution (1966‚Äì1976), Maoist zeal led to widespread destruction of religious buildings, texts, and artifacts. Temples, churches, mosques, and monasteries were closed or repurposed, and religious leaders were often persecuted, imprisoned, or sent for ‚Äúreeducation.‚Äù The aim was to eradicate religious influence from Chinese society and replace it with loyalty to the Communist Party and Maoist ideology.

Mao‚Äôs regime promoted scientific materialism as the official state philosophy, encouraging people to reject superstitions and religious beliefs. Educational programs were implemented to instill atheism, especially in the youth, who were seen as the future vanguard of the revolution. Religious practices were stigmatized and framed as backward or counterrevolutionary, and those who continued to practice faith were often subject to social ostracism or state punishment.

To understand how we could have ended up under Muslim rule without the Crusades, we must examine a few historical dynamics:

Early Islamic Expansion
The rise of Islam in the 7th century brought rapid territorial expansion. Within a few decades of Prophet Muhammad‚Äôs death in 632 AD, Muslim forces had conquered large parts of the Middle East, North Africa, and Spain (Al-Andalus). The advance into Europe was only halted at the **Battle of Tours** in 732 AD, where Charles Martel, a Frankish leader, defeated the Muslim forces.

title: Gregory the great- Against the papacy. #pope #popefrancis #catholic #orthodox #protestant #baptist
description:
I say it without the least hesitation, whoever calls himself the universal bishop, or desires this title, is, by his pride, the precursor of Antichrist, because he thus attempts to raise himself above the others. The error into which he falls springs from pride equal to that of Antichrist; for as that Wicked One wished to be regarded as exalted above other men, like a god, so likewise whoever would be called sole bishop exalteth himself above others....You know it, my brother; hath not the venerable Council of Chalcedon conferred the honorary title of 'universal' upon the bishops of this Apostolic See [Rome], whereof I am, by God's will, the servant? And yet none of us hath permitted this title to be given to him; none hath assumed this bold title, lest by assuming a special distinction in the dignity of the episcopate, we should seem to refuse it to all the brethren."

St Gregory the Great

19. Over the centuries, a number of appeals were made to the bishop of Rome, also from the East, in disciplinary matters, such as the deposition of a bishop. An attempt was made at the Synod of Sardica (343) to establish rules for such a procedure.(14) Sardica was received at the Council in Trullo (692).(15) The canons of Sardica determined that a bishop who had been condemned could appeal to the bishop of Rome, and that the latter, if he deemed it appropriate, might order a retrial, to be conducted by the bishops in the province neighbouring the bishop‚Äôs own. Appeals regarding disciplinary matters were also made to the see of Constantinople,(16) and to other sees. Such appeals to major sees were always treated in a synodical way. Appeals to the bishop of Rome from the East expressed the communion of the Church, but the bishop of Rome did not exercise canonical authority over the churches of the East.

title: Bede on justification by faith alone #solafide #protestant #catholic #apologetics #orthodox #faith
description:
Bede on James 2:25
AD 735
Although the apostle Paul preached that we are justified by faith without works, those who understand by this that it does not matter whether they live evil lives or do wicked and terrible things, as long as they believe in Christ, because salvation is through faith, have made a great mistake. James here expounds how Paul's words ought to be understood. This is why he uses the example of Abraham, whom Paul also used as an example of faith, to show that the patriarch also performed good works in the light of his faith. It is therefore wrong to interpret Paul in such a way as to suggest that it did not matter whether Abraham put his faith into practice or not. What Paul meant was that no one obtains the gift of justification on the basis of merit derived from works performed beforehand, because the gift of justification comes only from faith.

title: Chrysostom on Sola Scriptura #solascriptura #scripturealone #apologetics #catholic #orthodox #luther
description:
Chrysostom writing in affirmation to sola scriptura, don‚Äôt make even the most casual remark without the scriptures 

We ought not to deliver even the most casual remark without the Holy Scriptures: nor be drawn aside by mere probabilities and the artifices of argument. Do not then believe me because I tell thee these things, unless thou receive from the Holy Scriptures the proof of what is set forth: for this salvation, which is of our faith, is not by ingenious reasonings, but by proof from the Holy Scriptures...Let us then speak nothing concerning the Holy Ghost but what is written; and if anything be not written, let us not busy ourselves about it. The Holy Ghost Himself spoke the Scriptures; He has also spoken concerning Himself as much as He pleased, or as much as we could receive. Be those things therefore spoken, which He has said; for whatsoever He has not said, we dare not say. (Catechetical Lectures, 4.17ff)
John Chrysostom (344‚Äì407)

title: The Glossa Ordinaria, indicates a distinction between the 66 canon and the apocrypha.
description:
Many people, who do not give much attention to the holy scriptures, think that all the books contained in the Bible should be honored and adored with equal veneration, not knowing how to distinguish among the canonical and non-canonical books, the latter of which the Jews number among the apocrypha. Therefore they often appear ridiculous before the learned; and they are disturbed and scandalized when they hear that someone does not honor something read in the Bible with equal veneration as all the rest. Here, then, we distinguish and number distinctly first the canonical books and then the non-canonical, among which we further distinguish between the certain and the doubtful.
The canonical books have been brought about through the dictation of the Holy Spirit. It is not known, however, at which time or by which authors the non-canonical or apocryphal books were produced‚Ä¶Their authority, however, is not considered adequate for proving those things which come into doubt or contention, or for confirming the authority of ecclesiastical dogma, as blessed Jerome states in his prologue to Judith and to the books of Solomon. 

Glossa Ordinaria 13th century

title: Cajetan writes in his commentary to the pope, the apocrypha should NOT be used for matters of faith.
description:
‚ÄúHere we close our commentaries on the historical books of the Old Testament. For the rest (that is, Judith, Tobit, and the books of Maccabees) are counted by St Jerome out of the canonical books, and are placed amongst the Apocrypha, along with Wisdom and Ecclesiasticus, as is plain from the Prologus Galeatus. Nor be thou disturbed, like a raw scholar, if thou shouldest find anywhere, either in the sacred councils or the sacred doctors, these books reckoned as canonical. For the words as well of councils as of doctors are to be reduced to the correction of Jerome. Now, according to his judgment, in the epistle to the bishops Chromatius and Heliodorus, these books (and any other like books in the canon of the bible) are not canonical, that is, not in the nature of a rule for confirming matters of faith. Yet, they may be called canonical, that is, in the nature of a rule for the edification of the faithful, as being received and authorized in the canon of the bible for that purpose. By the help of this distinction thou mayest see thy way clearly through that which Augustine says, and what is written in the provincial council of Carthage.‚Äù

- Cardinal Cajetan
